normalised: so, you have probably heard about organic farming, right? it is not some fancy new fad dreamed up in Mumbai boardrooms, but actually a way of farming that harks back to the old ways, the way our grandparents, like dadi in her village near jaipur, used to do things. forget all the chemicals and synthetic fertilizers; organic is all about working with nature, not against her.

unnormalised: So, you've probably heard about organic farming, right? It's not some fancy new fad dreamed up in Mumbai boardrooms, but actually a way of farming that harks back to the old ways, the way our grandparents, like Dadi in her village near Jaipur, used to do things. Forget all the chemicals and synthetic fertilizers; organic is all about working *with* nature, not against it.
normalised: basically, organic farming is about growing crops and raising livestock in a way that is good for the environment, the animals, and of course, you! we are talking no pesticides, no herbicides, and no genetically modified organisms (G M O s). instead, farmers like mister sharma in his five acre plot near pune rely on natural fertilizers like compost, cow dung (plenty of that in india!), and green manure. they use crop rotation to keep the soil healthy and pest control methods that do not involve spraying harmful chemicals all over the place. think neem oil sprays and attracting beneficial insects.

unnormalised: Basically, organic farming is about growing crops and raising livestock in a way that's good for the environment, the animals, and of course, you! We're talking no pesticides, no herbicides, and no genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Instead, farmers like Mr. Sharma in his 5-acre plot near Pune rely on natural fertilizers like compost, cow dung (plenty of that in India!), and green manure. They use crop rotation to keep the soil healthy and pest control methods that don't involve spraying harmful chemicals all over the place. Think neem oil sprays and attracting beneficial insects.
normalised: why bother with all this extra effort, you ask? well, for starters, organic produce tastes better! seriously. and it is way better for you, no chemicals clinging to your kale. plus, organic farming is kinder to the earth. it helps build healthy soil, which can hold more water and reduce erosion – a big problem in many parts of india, especially during the monsoon season. it also protects biodiversity, meaning more varieties of plants and animals, which is crucial for a healthy ecosystem. doctor verma from the I A R I (indian agricultural research institute) has been doing some fantastic research on the benefits of organic farming and he reckons it is the future, especially for small landholders.

unnormalised: Why bother with all this extra effort, you ask? Well, for starters, organic produce tastes better! Seriously. And it's way better for you, no chemicals clinging to your kale. Plus, organic farming is kinder to the earth. It helps build healthy soil, which can hold more water and reduce erosion – a big problem in many parts of India, especially during the monsoon season. It also protects biodiversity, meaning more varieties of plants and animals, which is crucial for a healthy ecosystem. Dr. Verma from the IARI (Indian Agricultural Research Institute) has been doing some fantastic research on the benefits of organic farming and he reckons it's the future, especially for small landholders.
normalised: think about it: fields teeming with life, buzzing with bees, and growing healthy, delicious food. that is the picture organic farming paints. of course, converting to organic farming can be a bit of a challenge initially. yields might be lower in the first few years while the soil gets healthy again. plus, organic certification can be a bit of a bureaucratic headache (papers! papers everywhere!). and organic produce can be a bit more expensive in the market, maybe rupees twenty to thirty more per kilogram.
